Eclipse 3.1 M7?

I am having the exact same problem.  I just installed Eclipse 3.1 on my Windows
XP Service Pack 2 machine.  I installed VE from the Install/Update Software
within Eclipse.  I performed the following steps to (re)produce:

1.  Open up eclipse.
2.  Create new project.
3.  Go to File->New->Other
4.  Select JFrame Visual Class.
5.  Named the class Testing.
6.  Clicked Finish.

Eclipse goes to create the file, however I get the following three errors:
- Create Remote VM for Visual Editor for Java
- Create Remote VM for Visual Editor for Java
- Setup Java Visual Editor

Futhermore all of the three errors give the following details:
An internal error occurred during: "Create Remote VM for Visual Editor for Java".
tried to access method
org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.WorkspaceModelManager.getWorkspacePluginModel(Lorg/eclipse/core/resources/IProject;)Lorg/eclipse/pde/core/plugin/IPluginModeBase;
from class org.eclipse.jem.internal.proxy.core.ProxyPlugin.


I would like to use the Eclipse VE and any help in this matter would be much
appreciated.

Thanks,
Chuck Haines

I have the same problem in Eclipse 3.1,but it has not this problem in Eclipse 
3.0.2,you can try it!

Hey everyone,

It looks like you all have the common problem of updating through the Update
Manager.

The update manager will only pick up the latest releases of our product (1.0.1.1
or 1.0.2.1).  These all work for Eclipse 3.0, but not for 3.1.  There are many
major changes in Eclipse between the two version, and thus many major changes in
the VE.

Luckily VE is only days away from its 1.1 release, which will be picked up by
the update manager.  Until then to get VE to work on an Eclipse 3.1 install you
must download it from the VE homepage (www.eclipse.org/vep).

Download the latest release, currently VE 1.1RC1, and make sure you have all of
its prereqs (Eclipse 3.1 SDK, GEF 3.1, EMF 2.1).

Start your eclipse install with the command line (eclipse.exe -clean) to make
sure you reload all the plugins.  Once eclipse starts use Project->Clean to
clean all of your workspace cache files.

This should get you on your way to using VE on Eclipse 3.1.

This is due to a mismatch of some development drivers. This won't occur with the
released versions of Eclipse and VE. If you still have a problem with the
released versions, please reopen defect.
